div.p: 1. VII.Robert S. Garnett, a member of the House of Representatives, called upon me this morning, and told me there had been an explosion at Richmond— That to the great surprize of every body, Tyler’s Report, against the Anti-caucus Resolutions of the Legislature of Tennessee, had been indefinitely postponed by a majority of one vote in the House of Delegates of Virginia—77 to 76— George Sullivan, came with a draft of a Letter to Governor Eustis upon the state of the Massachusetts Claim— He asked my advice concerning it, which I gave him freely— I proposed to him several alterations, which he said he would make, and I advised him especially to avoid every expression which might appear to abandon any portion of the claim— He said MrCalhoun had told him he must classify the claim, for that the President would send it to Congress— But Sullivan added, it should not go to Congress. We all paid the usual New-year’s visit at the President’s; and although the weather was dull and rainy the company was unusually numerous— I attended afterwards at the Office till five, and despatched some business— We had a company of Members of Congress to dinner. Messrs. King of New York Talbot and Williams of Mississippi of the Senate— John S. Barbour, Cuthbert, Hobart, Holcombe, Isacks, Jennings, Kidder, Letcher, Mangum, Marvin, Sharpe, Talbot, and Wood— Mr Edwards, Senator from Connecticut and Mr Burton member of the House from North-Carolina were invited— But Edwards mistook the day of invitation, and came and dined with us last Thursday— Burton sent an excuse, having gone to pass his Christmas Holidays in Virginia— In the Evening I went in and passed an hour at Dr Thornton’s, where I met General D’Evereux, Mr Salazar, Mr Palacio and other Company.

div.p: 2. VI:30.S. B. Barrell of Boston came to my house and gave me two papers signed by several respectable merchants of Boston, Salem, and New-York, recommending a Mr Forrestier as Consul at Batavia, in the place of Soesmann. Crowninshield had recommended a Mr Shillaber, who has been a partner of Forrestier, and is a native of the United States— Forrestier was born at the Isle of France, but was brought up from a child in the United States, and in feeling and interest is altogether American. Barrell thinks him much the preferable man. MrCoxe of New-Jersey was here, applying for the appointment of Consul at Tunis, vacant by the Death of Townsend Stith— Coxe has been heretofore an applicant for the Office of Consul General at Algiers. At the Office, I requested of Mr Ringgold the Marshal his aid for keeping order on the Evening of the 8th. which he promised— At the President’s, I took a list of Nominations to be made to the Senate. The main question is upon the Judges in Michigan Territory. Letters from C. Hughes junr. at St. Petersburg 18. October— The President is not yet ready to answer the Call of the House of Representatives, upon Mallary’s Resolution— Evening Ball, at Mr Wirt’s— Very crowded company— Conversation with Crowninshield, who prefers Shillaber to Forrestier for Consul at Batavia— Questions from Sprague, concerning the Vice-Presidency; and whether a Legislative Caucus should be Republican or indiscriminate. Late home.

3. VII:30.Mr Southard; the Secretary of the Navy came to request me to write a Letter to Mr Petry, late Consul General of France, informing him that instructions have been given to Captain Creighton, Commander of the U. S. Ship Cyane, to accommodate him with a passage in that vessel to France. I spoke to him of the official Letter I had written him yesterday,
relating to two Resolutions of the House of Representatives, but he had not yet received them. Samuel Lathrop, a member of the House from Massachusetts, came to enquire concerning the state of our Northeastern boundary question— Mr Bliss a Commissioner for Massachusetts upon the division of Lands with the State of Maine had written to make enquiries of him— I informed him of the state of the Negotiation with Great-Britain, and lent him the two maps copied for Mr W. King— L. Rice was here, wanting more Stock of the Bank of the Metropolis—but I have none— At the Office— Mr Bailey spoke of the proceedings of the Committee of Elections in his case, with distrust; and the proceedings relating to it hitherto have been of an unusual, and not very fair character. The British Charge d’Affaires Addington came to enquire if I had any late despatches from England; but I had not— He was inquisitive as to the course we should pursue, if France should furnish Transports to convey Spanish Troops to South-America— I told him, it was yet to be considered— Mr Petry spent the Evening here— Cards. Call from G. Richards Michigan Delegate.

4. VII. Heard Mr Baker at the Presbyterian Church— In the Morning from Joshua 24.15. “Choose ye this day, whom ye will serve”—and in the afternoon from Psalm 36.2. “For he flattereth himself in his own eyes, until his iniquity be found to be hateful.” Mrs Lovell was taken ill, at the morning service.— In the interval, I called to see Mr Crowninshield, but did not find him at home. Called and saw Mr Poinsett and conversed with him upon Mr Webster’s Resolution, respecting the Greeks— I told him there was a person probably now at Constantinople, upon an errand, which might suffer by these movements in Congress. He said Webster would be satisfied, if the Government would appoint Edward Everett, as a Commissioner to go to Greece— There were objections to that— It would destroy all possibility of our doing any thing at Constantinople, and Everett was already too much committed as a partizan. He said Everett was to be here this day, or in a day or two more— He said Clay was threatening to come out on the affair of the Greeks, and probably would suffer in public estimation by the course he would take on it— Mr Blunt spent the Evening here— He gave me some information concerning the Hawkins Dauphin Island Contract, and the present connection of Coll. Charles Haine’s of New-York with it— Blunt spoke also in favourable terms of Mr DeWitt Clinton, and intimated that there were projects of Coalition between him and Mr Calhoun— I repeated what I had said to Mr M’Rae on this subject, and hoped no friend of mine would make advances of any kind to Mr Clinton; of whose talents I had a high opinion—with whom I had no personal misunderstanding, and with whose prospects I had neither community nor enmity. I had a visit also this day from Captain Chauncey and his Son.

5. VII— Displaced from my writing Room— Had a long succession of visitors at my house. Mr Crafts and afterwards Mr Mallary, members of the House from Vermont to recommend Mr Slade of Vermont, for the appointment of 4th. Auditor, in the place of Coll. Constant Freeman who is very ill and expected soon to die— Mr Tyler, son of Royal Tyler once an acquaintance of mine, came to solicit influence for the appointment of Suttler at Point Comfort. He pleads misfortune, and poverty; his own and his father’s, who has eleven children, and a Cancer in the head— He has been Chief Justice of Vermont, with a Salary of 1000 dollars a year. Mr Plumer
came with an application that the Historical Society of New Hampshire may be supplied with public Documents— Mr Fuller, introduced a Mr Thomson of Charlestown, one of his Constituents. He wants to contract for supplying the Navy-Yard at Charlestown— I had not time for much Conversation with Fuller— Jesse B. Thomas, Senator from Illinois called and introduced Messrs.Clendenin, Williamson and Hamtramck, Thomas’s step-son. D. P. Cook brought me a Letter to him from S. Sibley, former Delegate from Michigan; soliciting for an appointment as a judge there— Cook spoke much also of N. Edwards—of the President; and of the Mission to Mexico— I told him what the President had said to me respecting the part Mr Edwards was understood to have taken last Winter in the suppressed Document affair— Cook said that the President had alledged last Summer Edwards’s ill-health for not appointing him Postmaster-General; now a different reason was assigned for not appointing him to Mexico, and if what Edwards had done last winter had displeased the President, he must consider what he Cook had done, as having equally displeased him— I said there was a material difference between him and Edwards, in that affair— His conduct having been public, and in the discharge of public duties, while that of Mr Edwards had been anonymous, and intriguing— A partizan project concerted between Edwards & Ingham one principal purpose of which was to get Gales and Seaton displaced as Printers to Congress, and Calhoun’s printers of the Washington Republican appointed in their stead— Cook said he had known nothing of this design; though he had voted for Gideon and Way, as public Printers— And he admitted the distinction between his case and that of Mr Edwards— Mr Coolidge of Boston was here on a visit; and a young man named Phillips of New-York; nephew to the proprietor of the National advocate— These persons kept me at home till 2. O’Clock. I was afterwards at the President’s; and Mr Sullivan spent the Evening with me—conversing upon the claim.

6. VII. Bedchamber changed, and a perpetual bustle of preparation in my house, destructive of all regularity of occupation— I received a Note from J. Sloane, Chairman of the Committee of Elections of the House of Representatives, inviting my attendance before the Committee at 10 to-morrow Morning, to testify concerning the Election of Mr Bailey— Mr Van Wyck, a member of the House of Representatives from New-York came with his brother, who brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Sanford, now Chancellor of the State— I called at the President’s, and asked him if it would be agreeable to him to attend at the party we propose to give the day after to-morrow, to General Jackson, it being the anniversary of his victory at New-Orleans— We have invited all the members of both Houses of Congress, excepting Alexander Smyth and John Floyd— Their personal Deportment to me has been such that I could not include them in the invitation— To avoid inviting the President I thought might be taken as a failure of attention to him, though I did not expect he would come— He said he would think of it and give me an answer— This was the Evening of Mrs Adams’s alternate weekly tea-party; but the company was very small—not more than fifty persons— There was dancing, with the Music of the Piano. Ira Hill, the Geologist came this Evening, with his attendant, but said he would call again.

div.p:
7. VII. On my way to the Capitol, I stopp’d at King the Painter’s and paid him, for the Copy he has made me of the Portrait of Columbus; sent by G. G. Barrell, for Congress— Found Commodore and Mrs Rodgers, at King’s Gallery. I then walked up to the Capitol; and attended at the Meeting of the Committee of Elections— J. Sloane, the Chairman, with T. H. Hall of North Carolina, S. Tucker of South-Carolina, and P. Thompson of Kentuckey were there; as was also Mr Bailey— The Chairman handed to me a paper containing various questions respecting the appointment of Mr Bailey, as a Clerk in the Department of State, the time of his Resignation; and the Circumstances of his Residence in this City— I answered the questions verbally; and at the request of the Committee took the paper of
questions with me to answer them in writing. The Chairman Sloane, doubted whether he had authority to administer Oaths, which surprized me— After giving my testimony, I withdrew from the Committee, and went into the Senate chamber, to pass an hour. Thence I went into the House of Representatives, and heard a debate upon the admission of Parmenio Adams, as a member from the 29th. district of New-York, instead of Isaac Wilson who had been returned— Wilson had been ejected from his Seat yesterday, and Adams was admitted to it this day. The question turn’d upon the effect of one vote, through which the pen had been drawn— The inspectors of the Election rejected this vote, which was for Wilson, and the Committee of Elections, and the House, by a vote of 116 to 85 confirmed the decision— It was said that many of the votes in the House, depended upon another, and a non-apparent question, Wilson being for and Adams against a Caucus— Many of the members came and spoke to me; among the rest Mr Fuller, who said Mr Ingham had been with him and expressed great concern at certain newspaper hostilities against Mr Calhoun, in the National Journal, a paper recently set up here— He was exceedingly anxious for peace between me and Mr Calhoun— Fuller told him, that all he had seen of that character was defensive; and said to me that he thought the defensive only should still be maintained— I remained in the House till they adjourned, and then walked to my Office. E. Wyer came in there, and as I was going to dinner, I met Mr Connell just from Philadelphia. Mr Bailey called to enquire if a card of invitation for to-morrow had been sent to Mr Coolidge. Evening idle.

8. VII.Mr Bradley of Vermont called this morning and introduced Coll. Watson of this City. I called at the President’s, and while I was there MrCalhoun came with a deputation of five Cherokee Indians— This is the most civilized of all the tribes of North-American Indians. They have abandoned altogether the life of Hunters, and betaken themselves to tillage— These men were dressed entirely according to our manner— Two of them spoke English, with good pronunciation; and one with grammatical accuracy— This was a young man of 23 who has passed three or four years at a missionary School in Connecticut— He interpreted for his father, who made a speech to the President in the figurative Style of Savage Oratory; with frequent recurrence to the idea of the Great Spirit above— They gave us some account of their present Institutions; which are incipient. On returning to the Office, I found Baron Tuyll there— He read me extracts from two despatches which he has received from his Government— One expressing satisfaction at the explanatory paragraph in the National Intelligencer— The other stating the adjustment of the differences, between the Emperor Alexander and the Ottoman Porte— I told Baron Tuyll, that I should shortly send him a copy of the Act of Congress concerning discriminating duties. This being the anniversary of the Victory at New-Orleans, we gave an Evening party or Ball to Genl. Jackson, at which about one thousand persons attended— General Jackson came about eight O’Clock, and retired after supper— The dancing continued till near one in the Morning. The crowd was great and the House could scarcely contain the company— But it all went off in good order, and without accident— the President this Morning excused himself from attending, as I had expected he would— He said that when Mr Crawford went into Virginia last Summer, he the President had pointedly avoided meeting him—even when he was sick at Governor Barbour’s. And at the present moment, if he should depart from his rule of not visiting at private houses it might be thought he was countenancing one of the Candidates for the next Presidency, while he had so cautiously abstained from giving even seeming countenance to another.

9. VIII.Mr Brent called this morning at my house— At the President’s I found Mr Poinsett there. He was making some enquiries, for the Committee of foreign Relations of which he is a member. Whether it might be stated in debate on Mr Webster’s motion for an appropriation for a Commissioner to be sent to Greece, that the Executive is averse to the measure— Also what would be the views of the Executive as to an Act of Congress authorising the Blockade of Porto-Rico and perhaps Cuba—as a measure of defence or retaliation upon piracies, and piratical privateering— Poinsett stated that Coll. Cortes, and R. W. Meade who are now here, had written Letters against him when he was in Mexico— After I returned to the Office, Mr Kelly the Senator from Alabama was there—on some claim of indemnity for captured negroes— Inflammation of my eyes.

10. VII. Received a Note from the President, calling a Cabinet Meeting at one O’Clock— I met Blunt, and Mr Kelly the Senator from Alabama, as I was going to my Office— They detained me, till the President sent for me— I found Mr Calhoun and Mr Southard at the President’s— Mr Wirt came in afterwards— The first subject referred by the President to the meeting, was his draft of an answer to the Resolution of the House of Representatives upon Mallary’s Motion: which simply was, that there was no information upon the subject in his possession which could without inconvenience to the public service be communicated to the house— This was unanimously approved. The next was upon Mr Poinsett’s enquiries. As to his wish for permission to state in debate that the Executive was averse to the measure proposed by Mr Webster, Calhoun and Southard thought the views of the Executive ought not to be communicated in that way— I did not discuss the question; knowing that Webster had consulted Calhoun and Southard, before he offered his Resolution, and had been told by them that the Executive had no objection to it— As for the disposition of the Committee to authorise the Executive to blockade Porto-Rico and Cuba, Calhoun came out in the most decisive manner against it, and questioned even the power of Congress, to give the Executive such authority—because he said it would be War— This was the first time Calhoun had ever started a question upon the power of Congress, in this particular, and it led to much discussion, in which all the debateable ground, of that part of the Constitution of the United States was gone over— Since the argument upon President Washington’s proclamation of Neutrality, this has always been difficult ground, and the different views of the question have led to many curious and absurd results— Calhoun’s argument led to the conclusion, that Congress could not authorize the Executive contingently, to commit any act, hostile in its nature, against a foreign Nation— I referred to his own order authorising General Jackson to enter upon the Spanish Territory, in the Seminole War, to which he made no reply— Wirt thought blockading the Ports would be objectionable, because it would affect the rights not only of Spain, but of other Nations— I thought issuing Letters of Marque and reprizal, might be better— Calhoun thought any measure would be inexpedient, as tending to involve us in War upon a small point, just at the time when we had taken a bold stand, upon great, and general interests— He thought it best to make no other movement at present; but to look round us and wait for consequences— He said there had been no late captures, and there was no immediate danger— Wirt said Randall had told him, all the property taken by the Porto-Rico privateers and pirates would be lost, unless we should take some measure of self-vindication; and added that our Constitution was lamentably defective, if Congress had no power to authorise such a measure— I had no doubt of the Power, nor of the expediency, and thought that some spirited measure would be entirely congenial to the general attitude which we had recently assumed— Mr Southard was not decisive, and the President postponed his determination— He rather inclined against any measure himself, from an apprehension of offending England. Evening idle, from inability to use my eyes.

11. VII. Heard Mr Little this Morning. Job. 18.4. “He teareth himself in his Anger: shall the Earth be forsaken for thee? and shall the rock be removed out of his place?”— In the afternoon, Mr Baker, at the Presbyterian Church preached from 1. Timothy 1.15. [“]This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save Sinners; of whom I am chief”— Mr Baker’s afternoon Sermons, are not written; and he apologized for the defectiveness of this one, by observing that in the interval between the services he had been called to attend a funeral. In the Evening, I heard again Mr Little—from Proverbs 8.32. “Now therefore hearken unto me, o ye children: for blessed are they that keep my ways. 33. Hear Instruction and be wise, and refuse it not. 34. Blessed is the man that heareth me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.” This was a discourse addressed to the Children of the Society— Mr James Barbour, Senator from Virginia, and Mrs Barbour took seats in my pew, morning and evening— Mr George Hay and Mr Mosher the President’s private Secretary were also at the morning service, and afterwards called at my house— A gesture of surprize at seeing Hay there, prompted their visit— Hay is a philosophical unbeliever and seldom frequents any Church— I called at Sardo’s to visit some members of the Pennsylvania delegation; but they were out.

div.p: 12. VI:30.Mr Brent came this morning, for the draft of general Instructions to Mr James Brown, appointed Minister to France, which the President had since Friday, and sent me this Morning, with one proposal of alteration. It was accordingly made, and the draft was taken by Mr Brent— Mr Brody of New-York, he came here to accompany three Ladies from Tortola; and will be returning to-morrow. At the Office, Mr Elkins came to explain the alteration of the first toast given by me, at the Columbian Institute dinner— I gave “The flame of Patriotism kindled at the torch of Science”— They printed it, the Lamp of Liberty, lighted at the torch of Science. Elkins says, he gave it for the press, as I spoke it; but that Dickins, and five or six others changed it. He asked me, if he should rectify the publication, in the Newspaper— I said no— It was not worth while— Baron Stackelberg came— Urging again for a reciprocal abolition of all discriminating duties, in favour of Norway— I told him it was impracticable, and again explained to him why. He said the new Law gave them nothing, but what they enjoyed by the Treaty— I observed the Treaty would expire in 1826. the Law would not— I promised to send him a printed copy of the Law. Captain O’Brien came, and talked much upon his own affairs, and upon general politics— He gave me a copy of the printed circular from thirteen members of the House of Representatives, and one Senator from Pennsylvania, assigning their reasons for declining to attend a partial Congressional Caucus— This is apparently maturing into a great party question— The Legislatures of New-York and Virginia have declared in favour of a Caucus Nomination— Tennessee, South-Carolina, Alabama and Maryland against one— The movement of Pennsylvania, is even now not absolute, and decisive— It declares only against a partial Caucus— But it has the aspect of an effort in Pennsylvania, to take the lead of the affairs of the Union out of the hands of Virginia— There is yet room for much developement of policy between those States— Mr Fuller called also at the Office. And mentioned to me that Mr Mallary of Vermont would call at my house this Evening, which he did— He had much conversation with me upon the prospects of the Presidential Election; and upon his own views past and present. He mentioned also the dispositions of many other members of Congress, and among the rest told me that Mr Bradley, one of his Colleagues, was a partizan of Mr Crawford’s— Bradley himself, most distinctly and explicitly professes otherwise— Which is right? Mrs Adams and the family spent the Evening at Mr Wirt’s. Johnson Hellen to Rockville.

13. VII. Returned to my writing room, from which I have been eight days displaced. The succession of visitors is so continual, that I cannot duly attend to my business— This morning Coll. Dwight came, and introduced to me, Mr John Hunt of Detroit; a candidate for the appointment of judge in the place of A. B. Woodward— R. M. Johnson was here, with a recommendation of a Mr Edmiston for an office— Genl. S. Smith, and Mr James Lloyd of the Senate came to recommend that a Mr Boothroyd should be appointed as Agent, for certain claims upon the Government of Hayti, and furnished with a Letter to Boyer, giving him his title of President— I mentioned to them all the difficulties, in the way of this arrangement— They had mentioned the affair this morning to the President; and I spoke to him of it afterwards. He said he would refer it to a Cabinet Meeting— A Black woman and a boy, Slaves, came to ask contributions to purchase their freedom— The boy belonged to Mr Crawford— It seemed to me that asking a contribution for such a purpose, was craving alms for the Master; and not for the Slave. Mr T. Cook also called— Mr George Sullivan came to the Office. He had sent me a copy of a Letter to the President, upon which I made to him some remarks— G. S. Bourne came, and I despatched him with the Instructions for Mr Brown, who is at New-York— Bourne is to go to-morrow— Captain Biddle came, and gave me his account of his misunderstandings with Mr Rodney— I informed the President of what he said— His complaints were very bitter— A mob at Wilmington lately burnt Biddle’s Effigy. He says he is the injured man— I told him the President wished the whole affair, to be passed over, and forgotten— Mr Barrell came to press for the appointment of Forestier as Consul at Batavia— I laid before the President several papers for and against the re-appointment of A. B. Woodward as Chief Justice of the Michigan territory; with which he is much perplexed— After returning to the Office I saw the Delegate from the Territory G. Richard who is exceedingly earnest for the re-appointment of Woodward— There are charges of intemperance against him— Richard admits there was some foundation for them, a year and a half since, but thinks there is not now— Evening Ball at Mr Calhoun’s. Cherokees there; and a Squaw girl— Petry took leave of me— Going to-morrow to embark at New-York, with Mr Brown, for France.

14. VI:30.Mr G. Sullivan called upon me twice this morning, having in the interval been at the President’s— He told me that Mr Calhoun last Evening very peremptorily declared to him that the whole of the Massachusetts claim must go before Congress— And expressed himself inflexibly concerning it. There has been, Sullivan says, a total change in Calhoun’s views on this subject, since November, the motive for which lies not very deep— Calhoun is tampering with the Massachusetts federalists, for his electioneering purposes, and has discovered, that by paying that portion of the Massachusetts claim which he acknowledges to be unquestionably due, and not involving the constitutional question, he would confirm the ascendancy of the present administration of Massachusetts, by which the re-election of Governor Eustis would be secured— Calhoun has a personal grudge against Eustis, and despairs of success for his canvas, in the event of his re-election— I told Sullivan that during this administration certainly no part of the claim would be paid without going to Congress for an appropriation— While Sullivan was with me, Coll. Peter Little, a member of the House from Baltimore, came and introduced to me twelve Citizens of that place, visitors at Washington— Mr Hayden, a member of Congress from New-York came and introduced a Mr Edwards, and Benjn. F. H. Witherell, both from the territory of Michigan, and both here with reference to the judicial appointments to be made in that territory— There was a cabinet Meeting at the President’s; Mr Calhoun and Mr Southard being present; the question was upon the proposition to make Mr Boothroyd, the agent for claims on the Government of Hayti, and to furnish him with a Letter to Boyer, giving him his title as President of the Island— There was some discussion, but no diversity of opinion, manifested on this question— It was observed that it would be only a mode of recognizing, the free
government of coloured people in Hayti— Or at least would be so understood by Boyer; and it was concluded to be not advisable either to recognize them for the present; or at any time in that manner— The President suggested that Boothroyd might have a passage in one of our public Ships, and the Captain might land with him and introduce him to Boyer— But this would probably not be desired by the claimants themselves— I was at last authorised to give Boothroyd a Letter like that which was furnished to W. D. Robinson.

15. VII.Mr Edwards a Senator from Connecticut, brought me a Letter recommending a person named Brown, as Consul for the Island of St. Croix. The Letter mentioned that application had also been made in behalf of Brown to Mr Lanman the other Senator from Connecticut. In the course of the day, I received a Letter from Mr Lanman, asking the same place for his brother Peter— A Mr Goodlet from Tennessee came to state objections against the re appointment of Robert Purdy, as Marshal of West-Tennessee— He is a brother of the man, who complained of Purdy about his compensation as an assistant for taking the census— I had thought that affair was settled— I told Goodlet, Purdy was renominated— The Tennessee Delegation having taken much interest in his favour—particularly General Jackson, & Mr Eaton the Senators— This was in no wise satisfactory to Mr Goodlet— Mr Bradley of Vermont, and Mr T. Cook were here— At the Office, Coll. Torrens Charge d’Affaires from Mexico— He said his Government was anxious to have the boundary line drawn; and enquired if we would agree to appoint Commissioners, jointly with them to draw the line, according to the Treaty with Spain of 22. February 1819. I said the Article concerning the drawing that line, had failed of execution by the failure of Spain to appoint a Commissioner within the limited time. That now, we knew not in what light the king of Spain viewed the Treaty itself, as his ratification of it was one of the acts, that he had annulled— John Mason came and introduced Genl. Findlay; brother of the Senator and Member of the House from Pennsylvania— He wished to know whether the importation of Wood, into England, was permitted by Law— I found by the Commercial digest that it could. He said it could be raised advantageously in Pennsylvania. E. Wyer also came to the Office— We had company, members of Congress. E. A. Brown of Ohio Burleigh, Call, D’Wolfe, Hamilton of South-Carolina, R. M. Johnson, J. T. Johnson, Lee, Livingston, Martindale, Owen, Rich, Rogers, Sibley. J. B. Thomas and Van Rensselaer— Mr Addington and Mr Wallenstein spent the Evening here.

16. VII:30.Coll. R. M. Johnson came and introduced a Presbyterian Clergyman named Lathrop from St. Augustine— Mr James Strong a member of the house from New-York, came with Mr Whitney, from the Michigan Territory; one of the applicants for the appointment of Judges there— The testimony against the Chief Justice A. B. Woodward thickens and grows irresistible— Mr Mills, Senator from Massachusetts came; also to recommend Coll. Hunt. I was at the President’s, and he told me that he must give up Mr Woodward. I had sustained him as long as possible: but the charge against him of intemperance is too strong— The President said he would appoint Witherell, Sibley, and Hunt, judges, and Whitney, the District Attorney— He said also that he would appoint Coxe, Consul at Tunis and unless I should object, W. S. Smith as Consul at Tripoli— I had but a few days since supplicated the President, if he should give an appointment to Smith, it should not be an Office under
the Department of State. The President further shewed me a recommendation by eleven Members of the Pennsylvania delegation of George M. Dallas, to be Minister to Mexico. Mrs Adams with our two Sons, Mary Hellen, and Abigail Adams spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s— I spent it at MrMatthew St. Clair Clarke’s—the Clerk of the House of Representatives. There was a small party of sixty or seventy persons there—Members of Congress, and Ladies. There was Piano Music and singing; but no dance.

17. VII. The succession of visitors is endless. Many upon business, various to distraction. Many for mere visiting— The dissipation of mind that it occasions is painful— The tax upon the Memory insupportable— This morning, came Mr Lathrop the Clergyman from St. Augustine; for a subscription to erect a Presbyterian Church there— In all Florida there is not one Protestant House of Worship— Mr James Barbour, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations of the Senate brought a multitude of Petitions, of Claimants upon the French Government—Of two Classes—Before and after the Treaty of 1800— The claim indeed of those preceding 1800. is now against the Government of the United States; but Mr Barbour thinks it without solid foundation, in which opinion I concur— The claimants of a later date have a cause, much better than their present chance of success— Dr Spence, a member of Congress from Maryland, called for a friendly visit— Mr Rich, a member from Vermont, to enquire for some of his constituents of my opinions concerning the encouragement of Manufactures and the Tariff-Bill— I told him that as a general principle I was for the encouragement of Manufactures; but as to the details of the Tariff Bill, I could not answer how I should vote upon them— I was not called in the discharge of my Official duties to express an opinion upon the subject; and I should think it improper and indelicate to obtrude my opinions upon the public without necessity. There were various conflicting interests involved in this discussion; all of which were entitled to great consideration; and any opinion to be given should do justice to them all. Mr W. Plumer junr. came, and I settled with him the account of his advances for T. J. Hellen— John S. Barbour came with a claim of a constituent, for a Negro stolen away by the British in 1814. He afterwards called and left it at the Office— Mr Lowry, the Senator from Pennsylvania came to ask, about an allowance to be made to Condy Raguet at Rio de Janeiro. I told him it had been done, last July, and that he had received information of it in November. Mr H. G. Burton, Member of the House from North-Carolina, and Mr H. Seawell, Slave-Commission arbitrator came for a visit, and Mr Brent, member of the House from Louisiana, to urge the running of the boundary line with Mexico— He had a Letter of complaint concerning it, from Governor Robertson, and there is a defect of Jurisdiction upon the borders— I told him as I had told Torrens yesterday. Mr Fuller, of the House, called this morning; afterwards at the Office, and in the Evening again at my house. He had a proposed amendment of Mr Webster’s Resolution, to appropriate money for sending a Commissioner to Greece, the discussion of which is to commence on Monday next— The amendment would leave the appointment of the Commissioner, entirely at the discretion of the Executive— I told Fuller that it was quite immaterial what the modification of the Resolution might be—the objection to it under whatever form it might assume would be the same— It was the intermeddling of the Legislature, with the duties of the Executive— It was the adoption of Clay’s South-American system, seizing upon the popular feeling of the moment to perplex and embarrass the Administration— Fuller also told me of his Conversations with D. P. Cook, concerning N. Edwards’s disappointment, and the President’s reasons for not sending him to Mexico— And of his talk with Gales, who has been sounding him to know if I would accept of the Vice-Presidency, under a nomination with Crawford as President— I told Fuller, that I knew something of these Mines and Countermines of Crawford and Calhoun for the Presidency; they were disclosing themselves from day to day, more and more; and there was yet much to be discovered:
I told him how I had been treated by N. Edwards; and that I had nevertheless urged on the President his appointment to Mexico as strongly as with any propriety I could. That as to Mr Webster’s course, I should reserve my opinion upon its motives, for more conclusive evidence— Hitherto it was equivocal, and somewhat suspicious— We spent the latter part of this Evening at Dr Thornton’s, where there was a small company; with Mrs Bushby and two Miss Stedman’s from Saint Croix.— Met Mr Southard’s at the President’s.

18. VII.George Johnson was here this morning. I heard Dr Staughton at the Capitol. He preached from Proverbs 19.21. [“]There are many devices in a man’s heart: nevertheless the counsel of the Lord, that shall stand.”— After the service I visited R. G. Amory, Dodge and Morgan, then E. Everett at Dr Sewall’s, and Governor Findlay, Allison, and Farrelly, at Sardo’s. In the afternoon, I heard Mr Lathrop, at Mr Baker’s, from 1 Timothy 4.8. “Godliness is profitable unto all things.”— We had to dine with us R. G. Amory, Jos. Blunt, John Connell, and Mr Dodge— I asked professor Everett; but he was engaged— Mr and Mrs Sullivan, Dr Watkins and his Son, passed the Evening with us— I should have mentioned that at the President’s yesterday, Mr Southard read a draft of a Report to the President of a plan for a Naval Peace Establishment, upon which I made some remarks. Southard also sounded me as to my disposition with regard to George M. Dallas, whom eleven members of the Pennsylvania Delegation have recommended for the appointment of Minister Plenipotentiary to Mexico— I told him that Dallas was not yet of the standing from which Ministers of that rank should be taken. The President yesterday intimated to me that one of the reasons in favour of Dallas was the poverty of his Mother.

19. VI:30.Mr Farrelly and Daniel H. Miller two of the members of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, and afterwards two others, George Plumer and Robert Harris, came to recommend George M. Dallas for the appointment of Minister to Mexico— Farrelly had before recommended Henry Baldwin, for the same mission— He withdraws that recommendation because he says there is a difference of opinion concerning it in the Pennsylvania Delegation, and recommends Mr Dallas, not against Mr Edwards, but only in the Event that a Pennsylvanian should be appointed. Jonas Sibley a Member from Massachusetts came to enquire concerning a Lieutenant who served in the Boston Frigate in the year 1777. wishing to know, if there were any public documents which would shew a list of the Officers of that ship at that time. I thought he must go to the Navy Department, or to the Massachusetts Historical Society. At the Office, W. Findlay, Senator from Pennsylvania, came to recommend Edward Tilghman as Consul at Tunis, and a Mr Walker as Consul at Glasgow. Coll. Watson came concerning the judiciary appointments in the territory of Michigan; Mr Barrell with further recommendations for Forestier, as Consul at Batavia; General Call with sundry accounts for settlement from the Territory of Florida, and finally E. Wyer, who visits me almost every day. This Evening the first of many I passed at home and undisturbed—and devoted it to writing.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p:
20. VII.Mr Connell called this morning at my house with Mr Miller, the member from Pennsylvania and after them a Mr Salter— At the Office Mr Whitney of the Michigan Territory came to ask if consistently with the usage, he could see the representations from the Territory, for and against the candidates for the judicial appointments— I told him it was not usual— Mr Handy and Mr Coyle brought me a subscription paper, for an association for the relief of the poor. General Mason came and introduced Mr Griffith of Philadelphia, and his Son, and a Mr Patterson— Griffith has
an old and desperate claim upon the French Government, in the case of the Ship New-Jersey which he wishes to bring forward— After some conversation with me concerning it, he left with me a Memorial and a printed pamphlet relating to it. Wyer paid his daily visit, I received two Letters from A. B. Woodward, and two packets of vouchers relating to his conduct; intended for his defence against imputations upon his character. I took them to the President, but he had already sent to the Senate his nomination of Michigan judges, and had omitted the name of Woodward. I am not entirely satisfied this was right— Yet the testimony to his intemperate habits was apparently irresistible— Mrs Adams’s alternate weekly party was this Evening was well attended but not crowded— Dr Watkins told me that William King had assured him that my friends had agreed that I should be nominated in Caucus as Vice-President, with a nomination of Crawford as President— I applied an epithet to King for saying this, which I will not commit to paper. Adding that it was impossible any friends of mine, should have undertaken thus to dispose of me without consulting me upon it— Watkins afterwards said King had told him Fuller had given several indications that this was the disposition of my friends; that some opinions I had lately expressed about the Office of Vice-President, had been construed into such a disposition in myself: and that in three or four days a formal proposition to that effect would be made to me. This is the first unequivocal signal of distress, from the Crawford flag, that I have seen— And in my belief a fraudulent one too— But Let further developements come.

21. VII.Coll. R. M. Johnson came and introduced to me a Major C. P. Luckett from Louisville. Mr Charles Goldsborough, for subscriptions to his Naval Chronicle of the United States. Mr Gallatin who came yesterday from Baltimore; without his family— His correspondence relating to the claims upon France has been called for by a Resolution of the Senate; and he wishes to mark certain parts of it for omission. He came afterwards to the Office for that purpose— Mr James Barbour of the Senate, came also with papers concerning the petitions before Congress of the Claimants upon the French Government. The Committee of Foreign Relations of the Senate, to whom they have been referred, wish to have my views upon the subject in writing. Barbour told me of a Conversation that he had last Evening with the Count de Menou, Charge d’Affaires of France, in which he said he had told Menou that the fault of the Revolutionists in Spain had been that they did not take off the head of Ferdinand, and of ten or twelve thousand Monks—at which Menou was horror-struck— Barbour said he believed the success of the first period of the French Revolution had been owing to the vigour they had shewn in shedding blood. Mr Nathan of Philadelphia came to renew his application for the appointment of Consul at Tunis, but I told him Mr Coxe had been nominated. Mr Addington the British Charge d’Affaires came, and we had a conversation of an hour or more; chiefly upon the question concerning the Admission of our Consuls in the British American Colonies— Dined at Judge Thompson’s with a mixed company—Slave convention Commissioners, Corps Diplomatique, and Members of Congress. Miss Louisa Thompson gave us after dinner some music on the Harp— Evening at the President’s— First Evening Drawing-Room for the Winter— Very crowded— Mr R. King was beginning to speak to me, I suppose upon the subject which Watkins and Fuller had mentioned to me, when his brother William came up, and interrupted us by introducing young Storer of Portland to him— He spoke also of a Resolution, now before the Senate, which has passed the House of Representatives, requesting the President to send a Line of Battle-ship to France, to invite General La Fayette to this Country— Mr King thought it would be unnecessarily
expensive, and that a frigate would be at once more suitable and convenient. Mr Van Buren told judge Thompson, that it was very uncertain whether the New-York Legislature would pass the act—giving the choice of Electors of President and Vice-President of the United States to the people.

22. VII. The succession of visitors continues— This morning Mr Luckett came with a Letter from J. T. Johnson a member of the House— He is desirous of obtaining a place— A Mr G. Thomas brought me a packet of papers, which he wished to have referred to a Committee of the Columbian Institute— They relate to certain inventions in ship-building; about which he has quarreled with Commodore Rodgers, and the Navy Commissioners. Mr Newton, the member from Norfolk, came to speak of Mr Jeremy Robinson, who is again here; and who thinks he has not been sufficiently compensated for his services— I told him what had passed before, concerning Robinson— He spoke also of Captain Stewart, under strong prejudices against him. Mr J. S. Barbour came and introduced a Mr Long— At the Office. Mr Hemphill called to recommend Edward Tilghman for the consulate of Tunis. George Hay read to me an answer that he had written to a Letter from A. Stevenson a member of the Committee of Ways and Means, enquiring whether Hay’s Office of Agent before the Slave-claim Commission, was now as necessary as it had been last year— Hay’s answer was that he believed it as necessary, but he referred him to me for a further answer— Hay says that Stevenson wishes to frighten him from the stand he has taken against the Congressional Caucus, by threatening him with the loss of his place— I suppose Stevenson has also some resentments against Hay, on suspicion that he was the author of the Richmond Letters, in which Stevenson is charged with dishonourable practices— George Sullivan, brought me a Letter of Instruction to him and his colleague Peirce, and a private Letter to him from Governor Eustis, upon the Massachusetts claim— Sullivan has withdrawn the unsigned Letter in answer to that of the President of 22. December, and which was read at the Cabinet Meeting, and is now to write another—with regard to which he consulted me, and I gave him freely my opinion— Mr Miller of the house of Representatives likewise called, as did E. Wyer— We had company to dinner— Messrs.Allison, Daniel Brent, Cobb, Crafts, William Findlay, Gallatin, Gatlin, Locke, Neale, O’Brien, Richards, Ten Eyck, Whitman, and Wickliffe— Messrs. Bartlett of New-Hampshire, Branch, Herkimer, M’Kee and Palmer were invited, but did not come— Mr Gallatin sat with me half an hour, after the rest of the company were gone— There was a wedding party at Mr William Brent’s, to Mr Robert Brent lately married to Miss Cottringer— The younger part of our family, my sons, attended it— Mrs Adams was confined to her bed, almost the whole day.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p:
23. VII. The morning was interrupted by no visitors; an incident now of rare occurrence; and at the Office, I had only a call from Mr Crowninshield, who read me a Letter that he had received from Genl. Dearborn of Boston— I received a printed copy of a handbill, from Portland, Maine, containing a nomination, by the members of the Legislature of that State, for the Presidency. Mr Crowninshield, told me that William King, at my house last Tuesday Evening, urged warmly to him, that my friends ought to go into Caucus with those of Mr Crawford, to vote for him as President, and me as Vice-President; upon the principle that it is impossible I should be elected as President; and that the first place being unattainable, it will be the part of wisdom to secure the second— Crowninshield said he gave King no encouragement to expect the acquiescence of my friends in this arrangement
and he agreed with me that it ought not to be accepted— The younger part of our family dined at Mr Frye’s— And I went with Mrs Adams, and spent the Evening and supped there— Mr and Mrs Smith were there. Chess with Mr Frye— Walk with my Sons home. Mrs Adams quite unwell.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p: 24. VII.Mr Pedrick of Marblehead, brought me Letters of Introduction from my brother, and from Degrand— He has a project of going to Russia, to distil rum there, which I told him he would not find practicable— Coll. Hamilton, member of Congress from South Carolina came with a Letter from a brother of Captain Creighton Commander of the Sloop of War Cyane, in which Mr Brown is to go to France asking a delay of ten days or a fortnight, for Captain Creighton who has been ill, to recover his health. Hamilton said the President was willing to allow the time; but referred him to me— Coll. R. M. Johnson was here to recommend Mr Luckitt, and also a change of the District Attorney Steele at Pensacola, and a third Commissioner of Land-titles— Also to talk about the Caucus— The friends of Mr Crawford, are determined to hold one; but they now propose to make the invitation a general one, including federalists as well as Republicans— James Barbour the Senator from Virginia is the warmest champion for a Caucus nomination; and told Johnson that if nobody would join him, he—I byself I, would make a Caucus nomination alone— But Johnson said there was a question whether the anti caucus men should attend and vote it inexpedient, or absent themselves altogether from the Meeting— There was a meeting last Evening, convoked by Mr Ingham, chiefly of Mr Calhoun’s friends as the incipient measure of an anti-caucus organization— Johnson would have told me more, but we were interrupted. A Mr Whitcomb came for a subscription, to the publication of some books— Daniel Pope Cook came, and I had a conversation of an hour and a half with him, upon N. Edwards, the Mexican Mission, G. M. Dallas and Calhoun— I gave him an explanation of the real purposes of Webster’s Motion, for sending a Commissioner to Greece—much to his astonishment— Mr Bailey called to recommend a Mr Gough, now here for employment— General Call came upon West Florida business; and I found him very seriously averse to the removal of Steele, as District Attorney at Pensacola— Said he would see the President— Wyer was at the Office— Said something like a challenge had passed this day, between Clay and Bartlett in the House of Representatives— I dined at Mr J. M’Lean’s, the Postmaster-General, with a company chiefly consisting of the Ohio delegation in Congress— Mr Calhoun, Mr Letcher of Kentucky and Mr Clay’s son were there— Mrs M’Lean the only Lady. On returning home I found Mr Blunt at my house— My Sons attended a party at Mr T. Munroe’s.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p:
25. VII. Rain Storm, the whole day— Heard Dr Staughton at the Capitol— Rode there with Charles, and sent the Carriage home. The Sermon had begun before we entered the Hall, and the Dr abridged the service, for the inclemency of the weather. I visited Vice-President Tompkins who arrived in the City, and took the Chair of the Senate last Tuesday. He told me that he had recovered his health with the exception of sleepless Nights, and that he was relieved from all his embarrassments— That he had no intention of being a Candidate, either for election to the Presidency, or for re-election as Vice-President— All he wanted was justice— He could speak with a voice of thunder to the Legislature of New-York; but he had determined to take no part in the approaching election, and wished for nothing hereafter but quiet and retirement— I next called on John W. Taylor, and had with him a Conversation of nearly three hours with him— He and Mr Livermore had called at my house last Evening— The Presidential Canvassing proceeds, with increasing heat— The prospects in the Legislature of New-York are at present highly favourable to Mr Crawford and his party; and
the prospect that he will obtain the whole electoral vote of that State, has suggested to the friends of the other Candidates here the necessity of concert among them, in opposing him; and the first measure upon which this concert was sought was in the opposition to a Congressional Caucus nomination— At the beginning of the last week, Mr Ingham, and Mr Rogers, Calhoun’s Pennsylvania friends, sought meetings with other members, and last Wednesday Mr. Clay observed to Taylor, that while there was persevering concert, in the movements of Mr Crawford’s friends, if there should be none among his opponents, he would infallibly succeed against them all— There was therefore a second meeting on Friday Evening, where they agreed to hold another to-morrow Evening at a public house opposite to the Unitarian Church— Their first object is to ascertain individually the intention of every member, for or against a caucus nomination— On the other hand Cambreleng, a warm Crawford man told Taylor yesterday that the Caucus would be held; but not until April— That in the mean time there will be manifestations of public sentiment ascertaining beyond all doubt that there will be a majority of the Electoral votes for Mr Crawford; upon which his friends here will secure the co-operation of Mr Clay’s friends or of mine, by offering him and me alternately the Vice-Presidency; with the promise that by acceding to this arrangement now, the service to the party would lay up a fund of merit for promotion at a future election. And with reference to measures, Cambreleng said it was understood there was a greater coincidence between the opinions of Mr Crawford and mine than between those of any two other Candidates— I said I believed that was true— But I asked Taylor what he thought of Mr Cambreleng’s project with reference to political morality. Taylor said that when he had mentioned it to Livermore, they had both agreed it was a proposition which supposed the man to whom it should be made a fool— I told Taylor, I had been very sure that Crawford’s friends were at this game of playing off Clay and me against each other, but I should not have expected Cambreleng would have had the simplicity to disclose it— Taylor said he had been much surprized at hearing it from Cambreleng— I told Taylor that my mind was made up— I was satisfied there was at this time a majority of the whole People of the United States, and majority of the States, utterly averse to a nomination by Congressional Caucus—thinking it adverse to the Spirit of the Constitution, and tending to Corruption— I thought it so myself: and therefore would not now accept a Congressional Caucus nomination, even for the Presidency— And of course a nomination for the Vice-Presidency, in co-operation with one for Mr Crawford as President, could have no charms for me— Not that I despised the Vice-Presidency, or wished peevishly to reject the second place because I could not obtain the first— But because the People disapproved of this mode of nomination, and I disapproved it myself. I added that in opposition to such nomination, I wished my friends to take any measures in concert with others opposed to it, as might be proper— In effecting this concert, I wished them to dispose of me; as they should think best for the public service— I was entirely prepared to consider the election by the people of another person to the Presidency, as an indication of their will that I should retire to private life— Taylor said he thought my determination perfectly correct as to the Vice-Presidency—But that I should reconsider that of retiring to private life— That the mere failure of an Election to the Presidency could not be considered as indicative of the Will of the People that I should retire from the place that I now hold— A multitude of causes and of motives contributed to the issue of a Presidential Election— Sectional feelings—party prejudices, political management, and many others— I might still without dishonour, retain my place
under another administration— I said his observation was undoubtedly true in the abstract; and as his dinner bell was ringing, I would take another opportunity to explain to him my views on the subject—and in the meantime would come to no rash decision concerning it. I then called at Dr Sewall’s and invited him, with Mr Everett to dine with us— Then went to the Presbyterian Church and heard Mr Baker preach from Psalm 103.13. [“]Like as a father pitieth his children, so the Lord pitieth them that fear him.” The Storm continued, and there were only fifteen or sixteen persons at Church— Mr Everett, Dr Sewall and Mr Blunt dined with us— Judge Kilgour did not come— Johnson Hellen came from Rockville.

26. VII.Coll. Peter Little, member from Maryland came and introduced a Mr Walker of Baltimore. Mr Connell came about his claims upon Denmark and upon France— General Macomb brought and introduced a Lieutenant Webb, of the army; son to a Coll. Webb of our revolutionary War, whom I knew at New-York in 1785— Mr Dodge brought me a hand-bill of a Presidential nomination for Rhode Island; at Providence, 27 towns out of 31— This was unexpected to me, and though to the immediate object, of little importance, as an indication of general opinion there, calls for my most grateful sentiments— Mr Huntington came with a Letter from Coll. Trumbull, and the half subscribtion for his Print of the Declaration of Independence— Mr Gallatin was at the Office, and spoke to me of the Beaumarchais claim— Mr Tucker, Chairman of the Committee of the House of Representatives, left a Note to say he would call at my house to-morrow Morning. I received a Note from Mr Jones Secretary to the Commissioners of the sinking fund, requesting my attendance at a meeting at the Capitol at 11. tomorrow Morning— Eve at home writing.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p:
27. VII:30.Mr George Tucker called this morning to consult me with respect to the Report he is to make as Chairman of the Committee of the House of Representatives on the Beaumarchais claim— He said he thought the strict Justice of the claim doubtful, but that for the pride and honour of the Country it ought to be paid— A majority of the Committee were disposed to report favourably, but it was nearly certain the claim would be rejected in the house— He was therefore disposed to report that it should be referred to the Executive, for Negotiation with the French Government and he wished to know whether any proposal to that effect had been made on the part of France. Mr Gallatin told me yesterday that there had been, verbally to him by the Duke of Richelieu. I concurred with Tucker that the claim ought to be paid; as a repayment of so much of donation from the French Government; though as to the Million itself I did not believe the value of it had ever been received by us. I attended the Meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund, at the Capitol. Vice President Tompkins, the Attorney General Wirt, and myself were the only members present—Mr Crawford being confined to his house with an inflammation of his eyes. Mr Nourse, the Register of the Treasury attended for Mr Jones the Secretary to the Board. A Resolution was prepared, authorising the purchase of seven per Cent Stock, according to an Act of Congress passed the 22d. of this Month; and we signed it. The annual Meeting of the board, is to be next week on Wednesday— Our business now was immediately finished; and I went successively in to the Senate, and House of Representatives— I conversed with many of the members of both Houses. Mr R. King mentioned again to me that upon which he had begun to speak at the President’s drawing-room when we were interrupted; the rumour of a Coalition, between Mr Crawford and me, and our mutual friends, to concur in a Congressional Caucus nomination of him as President and of me as Vice-President—a rumour which he said was circulating both here, and at New-York. I told him that such overtures had been made to me and I had rejected them: and I gave him my reasons; the same as I had assigned them to J. W. Taylor
on Sunday. Mr King said the course that I had taken was such as he should have expected from me, and he thought the only one worthy of me— He said he had had some conversation with Mr Clay— From which he had learnt, that Clay, was for going to the Caucus, ostensibly for the purpose of voting it down, but to take his chance of the nomination if there should be a majority for it— He said his opinion was that Clay wanted to get into some public station, out of his own State; feeling his ground there to be shaking under him—and that he will push here, for any thing that he can get. King is much dissatisfied with the indications from the State of New-York; and I think does not yet see them in all their bearings— I spoke to Mr Seymour a Senator from Vermont, and asked him if he thought Mr Slade would accept of an appointment as a Clerk in the Department of State, at the Salary of 800 dollars a year— I told him I was afraid there would be a vacancy in the Department, within a very few days—Mr Maury being very dangerously ill, with an attack of gout, in the Stomach— Maury’s salary is 1400 dollars a year, but I shall feel myself obliged to advance L. Smith to that; and J. M. Baker to 1000. which is now Smith’s—leaving only the Salary of 800 dollars vacant. Seymour thought Slade would accept it, though the standing he has held, and his abilities give him strong claims to an Office of superior rank to that of a Clerk, even at the highest Salary— I made the same proposition to Mr Rich in the house; but he had doubts whether Slade would accept. Seymour and Rich however are to confer together before they give me a definitive answer— The House was in Committee of the whole, upon a Bill authorising Surveys for internal improvements, and Mr M’Lane of Delaware made a Speech in favour of it, but so many of the members came to speak with me on various subjects that I could not hear him— I spoke to Mr Baylies of the Resolution, Dr Floyd’s, calling for estimates of the expence of sending 200 men from the Council Bluffs to the Mouth of Columbia River— Said I was at the President’s yesterday when the Resolution was brought to him, and hoped the measure would be adopted— That I had urged the President to recommend it in the Session Message; and had again pressed him upon it yesterday on occasion of receiving a Letter from Mr Hogan the Consul at Valparaiso, mentioning that an American vessel had met a British one carrying supplies to the British Establishment at Astoria— I had also a long conversation, and some explanations with Mr Webster, upon his Greek Resolution: which was left undisposed of yesterday, by the Committee of the wholes rising without taking any question upon it— I told Webster that when his Resolution should have been finally acted upon, I should be glad to converse with him— He expressed a disposition to have the conversation now; and I told him the reasons why I had been averse to his Resolution— He said he had spoken to Southard at Sullivan’s, of his Resolution before he offered it. That Southard and Calhoun had both encouraged him to offer it; and the President himself had told him he had no objection to its being made. After I returned to the Office, Mr Hogeboom, a member from New-York called with papers relating to a Patent— I dined with a large party at Baron Tuyll the Russian Minister’s. And in the Evening attended a Ball and Supper, at Mr Robert Le Roy Livingston’s— A wedding party given to Robert Brent and his bride— Mrs Adams was unwell and did not go— The Vice-President and Mr Clay were there— I spoke this morning to Mr Bartlett, of New-Hampshire, about his quarrel in the House with Clay; with the result of which he seemed dissatisfied— I understood however upon enquiry, though not from him, that it was not intended it should go any further.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p:
28. VII.Coll. Richard M. Johnson came this Morning to urge with great earnestness the appointment of Craven P. Luckett as a Commissioner of Land-titles in West Florida; and the removal of Steele as District Attorney there. He gave me a bundle of Letters against Steele.— But the Coll. had
other objects of conversation— He is the particular friend of Mr Clay, as to the Presidential Election; and secondarily, a common friend of General Jackson, Mr Calhoun and myself— He has taken a strenuous part in opposition to the project of a Congressional Caucus Nomination, and is warmly engaged in the endeavour to harmonize the operations of the other Candidates and their friends— The Caucus is the forlorn hope of Mr Crawford. His friends have hitherto been confident, that in a general meeting of the Republican members, they would outnumber the votes of any one competitor, and thus obtain a final majority in his favour. The other Candidates and their friends are averse to a Caucus on various grounds, and Coll. Johnson has laboured much to unite them in opposition to the measure— He urges also the extension of this conciliatory concert to the formation of an administration— I told him that I would cordially contribute to this object, to the utmost of my power— That to this end I had authorized my friends in the pursuit of it, if they should think it expedient to set me altogether aside; and to concur in any arrangement necessary for the union of the Republican party, and the public interest. I reserved to myself only the discretion of retiring from the public service, in the event of the Election of any other Candidate— Johnson approved altogether of this course, and spoke of Clay, as being much exasperated against the friends of Mr Crawford— They have offered him the Vice-Presidency as they have to me; but they think he has not been quick enough to fall into their views, and some incidents have occurred tending to more than alienation between them and him— Johnson mentioned particularly the sharp altercation a few days since in the house, as an occurrence which had very much exasperated Clay. He spoke also of the quarrel between Bartlett and Clay; which I told him their friends ought to make up between them: which was just the easiest thing in the world; both of them having been intemperate in their expressions; and both having something to apologize for. He said it was very true; that Clay was the most imprudent man in the world; and had been altogether wrong, in daring the members of the House opposed to his opinions, on the Greek Question to go home and meet their constituents. A Succession of visitors followed Coll. Johnson—Mr Knight, Senator from Rhode-Island with a Mr Hicks, who has a claim upon the Government of Mexico— Mr Fuller; and after him Mr Van Wyck, the brother to the member of Congress from New-York— Van Wyck left two Newspapers with me, and spoke to me of the views of his brother, and two other members of the house from New-York. Mr W. R. King a Senator, and Mr Owen, a member of the House from Alabama came to complain of the change of one of the newspapers Printers of the Laws in that State— The change had been made at the instance of the two other Members of the House from the State— Mr Bulfinch came with Mr Henderson Inches of Boston— And Mr Pedrick came to enquire of the appointment of a Consul at Batavia— I called at the President’s and urged the appointment of C. P. Luckett; for which the President was however not ready— At the Office Mr Lowrie the Presbyterian Clergyman came to solicit the appointment of his Son, to the vacant Clerkship in the Department— Wyer to talk about news and politics. The Count de Menou, to enquire if any answer had been received from the Governor of South-Carolina, upon his recent application— There had not. and Mr Bailey to recommend sundry applicants for Office— I attended with the young part of the family an Evening party at Coll. Tayloe’s— Mrs Adams still unwell, did not go. Chess with Coll. Henderson. Fontaine Maury, a Clerk in the Department of State, died this Morning— Mrs De Bresson, wife of Charles de Bresson, a Secretary of the French Legation, and daughter of Judge Thompson, late Secretary of the Navy died also this Morning.

29. VII. Numerous applications for the appointment to the Clerkship in the Department vacated by the Death of Mr Maury—Hazel, Weymouth, Allison, applied personally, and many others in writing, all with strong recommendations, and pressed by urgent wants— If the condition were to be inferred from the multitudes of importunate solicitors for Office it would be a land of beggary beyond all others— Mr Seymour a Senator from Vermont called at my house this Morning, and again in the Evening— While he was with me in the morning, a notice was sent me to attend immediately the funeral of Mr Maury— Mr Brent, L. Smith and Johnson Hellen went with me.
He was interred at the burying ground North of Mr Crawford’s house. The service at the grave was performed by Mr M’Cormick— Ira Hill the insane Geographer was at my house, and Mr Lowrie the Senator from Pennsylvania— Amasa Stetson and a Mr Reynolds of Boston, likewise called— We had company to dinner— Messrs.Carter of South-Carolina, Eddy, Foot of Connecticut, Henry, Houston, Mallary, Mills, Senator from Massachusetts, Morgan, Plumer of New-Hampshire, Tucker of Virginia, and Williams of North-Carolina— Mr Barton, Senator from Missouri and Lloyd from Maryland, and Messrs. Gurley, Miller, Rankin and Storrs were invited; but sent excuses or failed of coming— Blunt was here in the Evening. Daniel P. Cook had been here in the morning— Seymour and Cook spoke much upon the course of politics and the fermentation of the Presidential Leaven at this time— Cook is agonizing for the appointment of his father in Law Edwards, for the Mission to Mexico— While Ingham and Rogers of the Pennsylvania delegation have started George M. Dallas, as a competitor to supplant him— Cook says Rogers told him that if the President did not nominate Dallas, he Rogers would never set his foot into the President’s house again.

div.p: 30. VII. The day was absorbed by visitors and applications for the vacant Office in the Department of State. Coll. R. M. Johnson, Mr R. King and Mr Fuller had long Conversations with me concerning the Movements of the parties here for the Presidential Succession— Johnson says that Calhoun proposed to him an arrangement by which I should be supported as President, General Jackson as Vice-President; Clay to be Secretary of State and he himself Secretary of the Treasury— Not as a bargain or Coalition; but by the common understanding of our mutual friends. I made no remark upon this; but it discloses the forlorn hope of Calhoun; which is to secure a step of advancement to himself, and the total exclusion of Crawford, even from his present Office at the Head of the Treasury— Johnson said that Governor Barbour, Senator from Virginia, after a Conversation with him, in which he had insisted, and Barbour agreed that upon an Election in the House, should it come there, the vote would be at least two thirds for me against Crawford, said he had thoughts of giving in his adhesion to me; which Johnson advised him by all means to do. Mr King spoke of the state of Affairs in New-York— His own views are in some respects biassed by his situation— He has been heretofore himself a Candidate for the Presidency— He had at one time during the present Administration hopes of being the next in Succession— There is a spice of disappointment in all his opinions—and his grounds of preference now are too much sectional— There is something peculiar in the state of his mind; for it is transparent in his conduct and discourse that although strenuous for the Northern Man, he would in the event of his failure, not be without consolation— King is one of the wisest, and best men among us. But his ambition was inflamed by splendid success in early life; followed by vicissitudes of popular favour, and hopes deferred till he has arrived nearly at the close of his public career. He has one Session of Congress to sit in Senate, but talks even now of resigning. Fuller mentioned the meetings which have been held and are holding to ascertain the number of the Members of Congress who deem it inexpedient at this time to make a Caucus nomination for the next Presidency— Coll. Dwight, Mr Rives a member of the House from Virginia, Mr Markley of Pennsylvania called also at my house— And Mr Hanson, for the Clerkship— At the Office Mr George Graham, a Mr Laub for the Clerkship, Mr Connell, who is upon his return to Philadelphia— Mr Pedrick about the Consulate at Batavia, and W. Lee to recommend J. B. Cutting— Evening at home, writing.

31. VII.Mr Ingham, a member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, called upon me this Morning; he is the principal leading member of the Republican part of the Pennsylvania delegation— He and Thomas J. Rogers, two years ago, got up Mr Calhoun as a Candidate for the Presidency— They were the movers of the recent circular signed by thirteen Members of the House, and one Senator from that State, declaring their determination not to attend a partial meeting of Members of Congress to nominate Candidates for the Offices of President and Vice-President: and they started the recommendation of George M. Dallas to the President, for nomination as Minister to Mexico. Mr Ingham having understood that I had objected to this nomination requested to see me to converse with me concerning it, and also concerning the course of conduct which the friends of Mr Calhoun have for the last two years observed towards me. We had not time to go through the whole subject, as I was obliged to attend the funeral of Mrs de Bresson as a Pallholder at 11. O’Clock: and Ingham is to call and see me again— He said that the recommendation of Mr Dallas, had arisen from a previous one of H. Baldwin which had given dissatisfaction to the Republicans of Pennsylvania, and the President had promised to appoint a Pennsylvanian, if the delegation could agree in the recommendation— That they had not at first been earnest in the recommendation, but since it was made an attack upon Dallas had been concerted by Binns an infamous man, with others in Philadelphia, and aided by Mr Lowrie, the Senator at this place: who were also endeavouring to overthrow the Republican Members here who had signed the circular— It was therefore in Mr Ingham’s view infinitely important to their retaining the republican ascendancy in Pennsylvania, that their recommendation of Mr Dallas should prevail, and that he should receive the appointment— I told Mr Ingham, that the stand made by the Pennsylvania Members, in which they had already been sustained by their Legislature, had placed Pennsylvania substantially at the head of the Union— It exhibited her as the Protectress of the rights of the People, and of all the smaller States, against the imminent combination of New York and Virginia— My objections to the appointment of Mr Dallas had been that he was not yet of the age and political standing suitable for that appointment, and could not be appointed to it without injustice to many others— That as to its bearing on the Presidential Election, I must be indifferent between Mr Edwards and Mr Dallas, both of whom are avowed partizans of Mr Calhoun.— I attended the funeral of Mrs De Bresson, who was buried at the Navy-Yard burying ground— The Pall-holders were Mr R. King and Mr Van Buren the two Senators, Genl. Van Rensselaer and Mr Lawrence two of the Members of the House from the State of New-York—Commodore Rodgers, and Mr Durant St. André the French Consul General, Mr Calhoun, and myself. Mr King, Mr Calhoun and I rode together to the grave: the service there was performed by Dr Lawrie— I returned home with Mrs Adams, and then went to my Office, where I saw Mr Reed, member of the House from Massachusetts, and Mr Bailey— Also Mr Brent and Mr Gurley of Louisiana who came again to urge the adoption of measures for running a boundary line with Mexico— In the Evening I attended Mr Goodacre’s introductory Astronomical Lecture.

Day. I rise usually between six and seven O’Clock, and idle away the time till near ten when we breakfast— Then till between one and two, I have a succession almost uninterrupted of visitors; some upon public business; applicants for Office; and political speculators— From two till five or six I am engaged at the Office or at the President’s—also with continual interruption of visitors— About six I dine; and then pass the Evening in company at home or abroad till eleven or twelve— This is a life so absorbed at once by business and dissipation, that I have scarcely an hour of the day for writing any thing. The Journal necessarily runs in arrear, and much public business is neglected. I seldom have been more dissatisfied with my waste of time, and yet I know not how to employ it more industriously. Would that this cup might pass from me—
